newsitem.title: USA: US Mid-Atlantic next-day power prices extend loss.
newsitem.headline: US Mid-Atlantic next-day power prices extend loss.

text.p: Spot wholesale electricity prices in the midsection of the Atlantic seaboard fell sharply Monday, extending Friday's decline on a plunge in natural gas prices and forecast of mild weather for the next couple of days.
Spot trading for Pennsylvania-New Jersey-Maryland (PJM) Interconnect electricity slowed midday after most players completed power scheduling for most of the week.
"Everyone was just into hourly and daily stuff," a Houston broker said.
Spot PJM prices were also pressured by lower-than-normal power demand for much of the week amid the Christmas holiday, brokers and marketers said.

Firm, peak PJM electricity for Tuesday and Thursday dropped nearly $10 a megawatt hour (MWh) to $18.50-$20.00 from Friday's range of $27.50-$27.75 for Monday delivery. Most deals for firm, peak delivery Tuesday and Thursday were scheduled at $21.00-$22.00, down from $26.00-$30.00 Friday.
Firm, off-peak PJM power for Tuesday through Thursday was notationally assessed near $14.00-$15.00 from Friday's $17.00.
On Wednesday Christmas Day, firm PJM power during heavy load hours were pegged near $21.00.
NYMEX January Henry Hub natgas futures were last down 37.8 cents per million British thermal units at $4.195, off from a 52.3 cent loss earlier.
January/February 1997 PJM power deliveries were pegged at $30.30-$30.65, down from Friday's $31.30-$31.50 with deals heard done today at $31.50.
March PJM deliveries slipped to $25.25-$25.50 from $25.40-$25.70 Friday.
First-quarter 1997 PJM fell to $29.00-$29.50 from Friday's notational quote of $29.50-$30.00.
Other deferred PJM prices stayed flat from Friday's levels as activities were at a stand still.

Second-quarter PJM remained at $23.15-$23.50, July/August 1997 $31.80-$32.10, third-quarter 1997 29.00-$29.25, fourth-quarter 1997 $24.00-$24.50 and calendar 1997 for peak hour delivery $26.40-$26.70.
The 1,055 megawatt (MW) Limerick 2 nuclear generating unit in Pottsdam, Pa., which was shut last Wednesday to repair a leaking seal, was scheduled to return on line today.

A 600 MW unit at the coal-fired Homer City, Pa., power station was heard still shut despite a planned restart this past weekend. The unit was taken off line a week ago to repair an oil feed pump problem.
